'''Hazel Meyers''' was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] and [[country blues]] singer. She spent most of her career in [[Black people|black]] [[vaudeville]], although on recordings she was billed as a blues artist.<ref name="AMG"/> Her more famous numbers included "Heartbreaking Blues" and "Blackville After Dark", both sung in her [[contralto]] voice.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Daphne
| last= Duval Harrison
| year= 1988
| title= Black Pearls: Blues Queens of the 1920s
| edition= 4th
| publisher= Rutgers University Press 
| location= New Brunswick, New Jersey
| isbn= 0-8135-1279-4
| page= 59}}</ref>

==Biography==
Meyers' recording career composed of a total of forty-one sides, the majority waxed between September 1923 and August 1924.  She saw her output released by several [[record label]]s, including [[Ajax Records|Ajax]], [[Brunswick Records|Brunswick]] (issued under the [[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]] banner) [[Pathé Records|Pathė]], [[Banner Records|Banner]], [[Bell Records (1920)|Bell]], and [[Emerson Records|Emerson]], with her final couple of releases appearing on [[Okeh Records|Okeh]] in June 1926.<ref name="AMG"/> Meyers had [[gramophone record]] releases on six different labels in 1924.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last=Oliver
| year= 1970
| title= Yonder come the blues: the evolution of a genre
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Cambridge University Press
| location= Cambridge, England
| isbn= 0-521-78259-7
| page= 262}}</ref>  Her accompanists variously included [[Fletcher Henderson]], [[Porter Grainger]], [[James "Bubber" Miley]], [[Leslie Hutchinson|Leslie "Hutch" Henderson]] and [[Don Redman]], plus on one recording, [[Fats Waller]].<ref name="AMG"/> Meyers' tracks included the first female vaudeville artist recording of the satirical song, "[[Black Star Line]]", released in May 1924.  The song was recorded by both Meyers and [[Rosa Henderson]] within a twenty four hour period.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Robert
| last= Springer
| year= 2006
| title= Nobody Knows Where the Blues Come from: Lyrics and History
| edition= 1st
| publisher= The University Press of Mississippi 
| location= Jackson, Mississippi
| isbn= 1-57806-797-9
| page= 198}}</ref> 

One source speculated that Meyers also recorded under the pseudonyms of Mae Harris for [[Domino Records (before 1993)|Domino]], and Louella Smith for [[Oriole Records (U.S.)|Oriole]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= Allan
| last= Sutton
| year= 1993
| title= A Guide to pseudonyms on American records, 1892-1942
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Greenwood Press 
| location= Westport, Connecticut
| isbn= 0-313-29060-1
| pages= 22 & 44}}</ref>

Meyers appeared in vaudeville throughout the 1920s.  Detailed information is not available, but she did appear in ''Steppin' High'', a variety show staged in [[Harlem]], [[New York City|New York]], where she was backed by the orchestra of Fletcher Henderson.  More generally, she is believed to have made regular appearances in the theater until the early 1930s.<ref name="AMG"/>

However, little is known of life outside of her professional engagements.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p201904|pure_url=yes}}|title=Hazel Meyers|author=Uncle Dave Lewis |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=September 26, 2011}}</ref> 

Meyers entire recorded work was made available in 1996 by [[Document Records]].<ref name="Compilation">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r250628/credits|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 1 (1923-24)'' > Review )))}}</ref><ref name="Hicks">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=complete-recorded-works-vol-2-1923-27-r250661|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 2 (1923-27) - Edna Hicks et al )))}}</ref>
